content: one of the more frequent comments I get
is hey I can't get my tiles to look quite as crisp as yours I get gaps
between them on the table why is that the answer is that your material is
probably not return to square so I thought I'd take a moment here and talk
about that after all US cardboard men and women have it tough we ain't got no
fancy little practice and hot wire table cutters to cheat our way to precision no
we keep surreal we keeps it old-school to be clear here's the issue that I get
asked about you make some tiles and then you find that there's gaps but the root
of the problem is usually one of two things either you have a bulge in your
corrugation cladding or your foundation wasn't square instead of a square you
cut a slight rhombus for your foundation to mitigate this ensure that your
material itself is square before you start measuring and cutting up so you
got a slab a corrugated cardboard here could be any material I'll do some foam
board in a moment but anyway corrugated cardboard from your scrap pile no idea
if it's square notice that you can see the ridges of the corrugation through
the paper on one side pick one of those ridges and make a pencil mark on it at
two locations which are far away whenever you measure out a line the
farther away you make the two marks the more accurate the line will be now
instead of trying to line up your ruler on those two marks instead plant the tip
of your knife on one of them scoot the ruler up and then pivot the ruler so it
hits the other mark this seems trivial but trust me is a lot easier and that
time adds up anyways cut through it multiple passes for corrugated cardboard
now we have one known perfect edge and we need to draw a perpendicular line so
use a square like a carpenter's square or a speed square heck anything we'll do
a CD case even a sheet of printer paper anything you know has a factory perfect
90-degree angle will work just touch the edge of the material with your fingers
and slide the object up so it touches and you'll be able to feel when it's
flush with the edge then draw the perpendicular line and use
a ruler to guide the cut now you have a factory perfect 90-degree corner to
perfect edges so whenever you measure out something like perhaps tile
foundations always measure from those two edges ignore the other two also if
you know you're going to be cutting a lot of pieces measure all those lines at
once and then cut don't cut a row of squares and then measure and cut another
and measure and cut another that's bad because if you have even a slight error
like a subtle shift or your ruler or something it will propagate so no
measure out everything on the slab first then cut it out here's a hunk of foam
board no corrugation on this so I'm just gonna pick anywhere pick one side
ideally near an edge and cut so this makes our first perfect edge and just as
before use a square to draw and cut a perpendicular line always measure from
your two factory edges a good way to test how well you did is by feel
here's two tile foundations two and a half inch squares when I stack them
together and run my fingers along the edge I can feel that they're perfectly
flush in both directions then I rotate one of them 90 degrees and feel again if
they're still flush in both directions then you know that they're square two
other quick tips for quality precision cutting use a good amount of pressure to
pin your ruler in place might be a little more than you think
if you still have problems this might be it it cannot move that's crucial use
multiple passes with moderate pressure don't try and cut through all at once
and pay attention to the angle of your knife relative to the table make sure
you're not tilting it left or right it's helpful to stand directly behind your
cut and pull it towards you so that you can keep an eye on this hopefully all
this was helpful to you and keep it in mind for next episode because we're
really gonna need it please don't hesitate to hit that like button
subscribe reminders etc etc there is a link in the description below from my
amazon storefront easy free way to support the channel if you want just buy
your stuff through that link and for all you 3d printers out there while ochs
crafting vids is sponsored by heroes horde which has an excellent range of
high-quality models including but not limited to all true tiles
which are open lock compatible also check out my modules over on the DMS
guild and remember $3 patrons get free copies of all my releases if you liked
this particular project here's two more that you should go check out right now
also enjoy this month's community showcase and don't forget to subscribe
and click that Bell reminder icon I am why lock thanks for joining me and I'll
see you next time
